attributes.title: Individual differences in vagal system function during emotion processing in MIDUS Refresher
attributes.description: The Midlife in the United States (MIDUS) Refresher study provides an excellent opportunity to examine the relationship between HRV and emotion regulation across a diverse sample of United States adults. We hope to expand upon previous findings in the MIDUS II sample by examining the relationship between resting baseline measures of HRV and psychophysiological indicators of emotional reactivity and recovery within an emotional picture viewing paradigm. Indicators of emotional reactivity and recovery will be quantified by activity in corrugator and zygomaticus EMG and startle EBR during multiple timepoints.

attributes.title: Self-compassion as a buffer on self-threat driven prejudice: a conceptual replication

q1.value: Self-compassion as a buffer on self-threat driven prejudice: a conceptual replication

q3.value:
Judgments or evaluations individuals hold of others may be one of the root causes of flourishing in relationships, groups, and organizations. In contrast, prejudices can both lead to interpersonal conflict and thwart belonging. Removing prejudices (and ideally replacing them with positive feelings towards others) is a key step towards a flourishing society. What is at the root of these judgments? What can be done to prevent them? Fein and Spencer (1997), among others, showed that giving people a threat to their self-image, via a fake low score on an intelligence test, lead them to express greater prejudice towards others. Sinclair and Kunda (1999) showed a similar a result, and claim that biases lead to motivated reasoning and prejudice. From a theoretical perspective, numerous biases skew judgment, including judgments of other people. The need to see one’s self in an overly positive light plays a central role in many of these biases, termed “positive illusions” (Taylor & Brown, 1988). Though these illusions are argued to be adaptive (Taylor & Brown, 1988), there are also many costs. Crocker and Park (2004) document various drawbacks of overfocus on one’s self-image, such as increased aggression and mental health problems. Over the last twenty years or so, much research has documented dangers of this judgmental self-esteem and presented alternatives. True self-esteem (Kernis, 2003), autonomous motivation (Deci & Ryan, 2000), implicit self-esteem (Bananji & Greenwald, 1995) growth mindset (Dweck, 1998), mindfulness (Ryan & Brown, 2003), and self-compassion (Neff, 2003) each describe alternative ways to view one’s self that retain the benefits of self-esteem without the costs.  
Self-compassion, in particular, represents an alternative to more judgmental forms of self-esteem that has a large body of research and a solid theoretical ground. A review by Baumeister et al. (2003) showed that self-esteem as typically measured by psychologists  actually does not have as many adaptive benefits as once thought. Shortly thereafter, Neff and Vonk (2009) showed that benefits of self-esteem, such as less anger, more positive affect, less closed-mindedness, and less social comparison, are mostly eliminated when controlling for self-compassion. Self-compassion is defined as an orientation towards treating one’s self with kindness and having less of a need to evaluate one’s self, whether positive or negative (Neff, 2003). When given potentially threatening information about themselves, people with higher self-compassion react less defensively and take personal responsibility for their shortcomings (Leary et al., 2007). Underlying processes such as feeling more secure about one’s self, yet focused less on evaluating one’s self, appear to drive such reactions. Applied to prejudice research, people with self-compassion should feel less of a need to maintain a positive self-image under self-esteem threat and, when threatened, not increase in prejudice towards others.  Previous research we have conducted has shown this effect. However, we seek to replicate this effect with a slightly different operationalization to strengthen the evidence.

q4.value:
The main hypothesis is that self-compassion will moderate the effect of a self-esteem threat on prejudice. Specifically, participants higher in self-compassion will shower smaller increases in prejudice when given a self-esteem threat.

We also predict that self-esteem threat will lead to an increase in prejudice.

Finally, we predict that the effects of the self-esteem threat will be mediated by externalizing, defined as derogating the validity of the test, and not by negative affect

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
When the study begins, participants will be directed to the computer lab. Up to 25 participants will be allowed to participate in each slot, and instructions will be given to the entire group. First, participants will be given verbal instructions. "Thank you again for helping out with this study. This study explores how social intelligence relates to general intelligence, and how different personal characteristics modify this relationship. First, you will begin by answering several questions about demographic information and attitudes you hold, such as personality questions. Next, you will take a social intelligence test. This test requires you to first guess what emotion people are feeling based off of their facial expression, and then evaluate whether or not five real-life couples will stay together or separate. Next, you will be asked to take a general intelligence test. This test includes a couple of verbal and mathematical tasks requiring multi-tasking. This tests asks you to multi-task to get a better measure of your overall intellectual capacity. These tasks require you to either think about another person or listen to another person, which helps link the general intelligence test to the social intelligence test. After you finish, come to the front desk and I will have a couple of questions to ask you. Before you begin, read and sign your consent form, and then hand it to me. You may then begin the survey: a link is written on the white board." Participants will then be asked to hand the experimenter their consent form before beginning the survey. After a quick sound check on each participant's computer, the survey will first ask demographic questions and then all of the other instruments about personal characteristics, such as self-compassion and big 5 personality. Next, they will take the social intelligence test. The first task asks them to identify the emotion from a face. The second task gives them 60 seconds to read a description of a couple and predict whether or not they will stay together.  Then, participants will get feedback. They will be randomly assigned by Qualtrics to one of three conditions: negative feedback (told they are in the 25th-30th percentile), no feedback (they go straight to the intelligence test), or positive feedback (told they are in the 70-75th percentile).  Next, participants will take a supposed general intelligence test. This test purportedly uses multi-tasking to measure overall intellectual capacity. For the first task, participants will listen to a 2-minute excerpt of the book Great Expectations. They will be asked to count how many words begin with "p" will simultaneously filling in word fragments. This task serves to bolster the cover story. Then, participants will be asked to perform mathematical operations while simultaneously evaluating a resume.  After completing this task, participants will be probed for suspicion by being asked to answer whether anything seemed unusual, what they guessed the hypothesis was, and when they guessed the hypothesis, if they thought they guessed it. They will also be asked how they felt about their performance on the social intelligence test.  Finally, participants will be asked to report to the experimenter for a debriefing. The experimenter will read the debriefing sheet, which explains the rationale for deception, the study, and assures participants that the feedback they got was fake. Participants will be told that they can remove their data by informing the experimenter at that moment, and that they may use BYU CAPS (Counseling) if they are having trouble with negative emotions or self-perceptions after the study. 

See attached IRB for more detailed explanation

q9.value: We will randomize at the individual level. The software that we are using for the survey will randomly assign participants to see either negative or positive feedback, evenly presenting both conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will put this study upon on the Brigham Young University (BYU) Psychology Department SONA system, which is open to any BYU student taking those classes. Students under the age of 18 will not be allowed to participate in this study. Each student will receive 4 SONA credits, which, depending the professor and course, may be used towards a required class assignment or for extra credit. We expect that this study will take about 30-35 minutes. The department compensates participants such that every ten minutes of participation yields 1 SONA credit.

q14.value: The institutional review board has approved this study until the beginning of April. Given that we only have 2 research assistants to run the study, we can expect about 25 participants per week, with 8 weeks of data collection.

q15.value: We will target the sample size of 200. If we reach the target prior to our study deadline, we will stop. Otherwise, we will continue to collect data until the deadline, at which we will terminate the data collection

question.value: We manipulate whether participants receive positive feedback or negative feedback on their social intelligence test. Positive feedback is defined as being told their score was in the 70-75th percentile and that this indicates good social ability. Negative feedback is defined as being told their score was in the 25-30th percentile and that this indicates they are somewhat socially inept.

Trait self-compassion: This variable will be defined as a person's score on the short-form self-compassion scale (Raes et al., 2011)* - This 12-item scale measures self-compassion, central to our hypothesis, and showed nearly identical results to the 36-item scale. We choose to use the 12-item scale to put less of a cognitive burden on participants. 

Prejudice: Defined as participant rating of candidate competence (Shapiro et al., 2010)**. This rating will be used as our measure of prejudice. It asks participants, on a 1 to 9 scale, to rate the candidate on 11 different questions (e.g. how competent, how likely to take a leadership role, how qualified for the position) .

Need for Closure: Defined as participant score on Need for Closure Brief Scale (NFC-15, Roets; Van-Hael, 2011)**, this characteristics relates to how much people feel they have to have a sense of cognitive closure or control in their lives, and has been theorized to be a motivating factor in prejudice. Though not part of the main hypothesis, we wanted to explore possible interactions with self-compassion. 

Negative Affect: We have several questions that ask participants how they felt after receiving the feedback (e.g. hurt, threatened, elated) on a scale from 1 to 11. We will use the factors that emerged using EFA on pilot data to create scales that measure negative affect.

Externalizing: 
We have several questions that give participants the opportunity to blame the test for their bad score or derogate the test. Using pilot data, we will choose the top 4 items that
1. Have the highest criterion validity (defined as predicting responses to prejudice under threat)
2. Have a reliability of at least .7.

If the reliability is less than .7, we will drop the item that has the smallest correlation with the other items, and add the item with the next highest criterion validity.
Not applicable

Exclude participants that fail attention check (more than 2/3rds of attention check questions incorrect).

The main model will, using Stata, regress prejudice on a dummy variable for condition, self-compassion (centered), and an interaction term.

Further models will examine adding self-esteem (centered) and its interaction with condition (model 2), adding controls for the big 5 personality scales.

Lastly, we will examine the hypothesis for mediation. First, we will look at negative affect and externalizing as dependent variables. Then, we will add negative affect and externalizing to the model. We will use the method described by Shrout and Bolger (2002) to estimate the confidence intervals of the indirect effects.

q20.value: I do not plan on transforming any data. Self-compassion will be mean-centered.

q22.value:
Pilot data indicated that prejudice was seen most clearly in white participants. Thus, we will exclude data from participants who do not indicate their race is white/caucasian.

Data will be analyzed in 3 ways: as normal, excluding outliers on the dependent variable (plus or minus 2 IQR from the median), and a regression robust to outliers using the rreg command in Stata. All results will be presented. Robustness will provide stronger evidence, while a result that is significant only in one model specification will be consider weaker support for the hypothesis.

q23.value: Missing data is not expected to be a major problem given participants will be participating in lab. For those who are missing on the dependent variable or on self-compassion, we will exclude them from the analysis. Patterns of missingness will be explored and reported.

q24.value:
We will also look at the interactions between need for cognitive closure (NCC) and self-esteem threat & NCC and self-compassion predicting prejudice.

Additionally, we will run post hoc analyses to check for experimenter effects.

attributes.title: Are patient portals being used to support palliative and end-of-life care? A scoping review
attributes.description: Current patient portal research targets portal engagement with health care utilization and clinical outcomes. Little is known about the utility of patient portals for improving palliative care and end-of-life (PCEOL) health outcomes. Our scoping review will examine how patient portals are currently being used for PCEOL. Our research questions include: 1) What PCEOL tools or interventions are available to patients and caregivers? 2) What are patient and caregiver perspectives about using portals in the PCEOL setting?

q2.value:
Current patient portal research targets portal engagement with health care utilization and clinical outcomes. Little is known about the utility of patient portals for improving palliative care and end-of-life (PCEOL) health outcomes. Our scoping review examines how patient portals are currently being used for PCEOL. Our research questions include:
1) What PCEOL tools or interventions are available to patients and caregivers? 
2) What are patient and caregiver perspectives about portals in the PCEOL setting?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We are conducting scoping review of patient portals. Our data sources include: a) document review of commercially available patient portal services; and b)  literature review of palliative care and end of life (PCEOL) patient portal research.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
For the document review of current commercially available PCEOL tools , we will contact 10 patient portal companies to request service information. For the academic literature, we will search Ovid Medline with search terms that includ “patient portal” in combination with PCEOL terms.

Documents and articles will be examined to identify PCEOL elements of symptom management, quality of life assessment, psychosocial support, decision support, bereavement and grief, spiritual care, and patient/family education.  Authors will independently review papers for inclusion and assessment of PCEOL tools and user perspectives. Articles will be tracked used Covidence software.

q11.value: We anticipate identifying approximately 50-100 articles related to PCEOL and patient portals.

question.value: Not applicable

Documents and articles will be examined to identify PCEOL elements of symptom management, quality of life assessment, psychosocial support, decision support, bereavement and grief, spiritual care, and patient/family education.

Not applicable.
Scoping review results will be descriptive in nature.

attributes.title: Adverse events associated with botulinum toxin A injection in the treatment of the upper and lower limbs muscles spasticity and dystonia: a systematic review with meta-analysis.
attributes.description: Neuromuscular block with the injection of botulinum toxin type A is one of the treatment of spastic hypertonia or dystonia. To date, this treatment is considered safe, severe adverse events are described in few cases, most of harms are minor and tolerable. In previous published reviews, authors analysed only partially the most frequent aspects related to the usual clinical setting in which our group operate (e.g. works which did not consider all the botulinum toxin type A formulations, or limited to restricted anatomical districts, or focused just on post-stroke spasticity).  Specifically, the aim of this review is to add further information to the actual knowledge by searching for studies which considered all the botulinum toxin type A  formulations in the management of limbs’ muscles spasticity or dystonia as positive features of upper motor neuron syndrome. At this point, to better quantify the safety and adverse events related to neuromuscular block with botulinum toxin, we consider important that the comparison should be made with placebo or other treatment. This work could represent a useful informative instrument for clinicians and patients about the safety of this therapy and any eventual peri-procedural complication.

q1.value: William Campanella, Giulia Maggi, Sabrina Mesmaeker, ELENA SARETTI, Tiziano Innocenti, Luca Carmisciano, gianmarco rosa, Lucio Marinelli, LAURA MORI, Carlo Trompetto

q2.value: Spasticity and dystonia affect motor function and ability to perform activity of daily living, with an important impact on patients and caregivers’ quality of life. Intramuscular administration of botulinum toxin type A is one of the treatment of spastic hypertonia or dystonia. The aim of this systematic review is to evaluate the risk of any kind of local or systemic adverse events due to botulinum toxin type A injection in the management of upper and lower limb muscles spasticity and dystonia as positive features of upper motor neuron syndrome.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This systematic review with meta-analysis was designed following the Preferred Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) harms checklist.
We will search the following electronic bibliographic databases MEDLINE, EMBASE, British Library, the Cochrane Central, Scopus, PEDRO, Web of Science, ClinicalTrials.gov. grey literature (E.g. Google scholar, direct contact with experts in the field of physical medicine).
We intend to consider only English language published papers, with no temporal limits of publication. In addition of the search strategy, references of relevant reviews and retained articles will be reviewed to identify additional significant articles.

"Details of the types of study (study designs) eligible for inclusion in the review"
Inclusion criteria: randomized controlled trials.
Exclusion criteria: non-randomized controlled trials, studies lacking sufficient reporting detail (number of patients per group, type of intervention, number of adverse events per group), review articles, meta-analysis, consensus guidelines, case reports or series, editorials and other non-clinical trials will be excluded.

"Main outcome"
Incidence of adverse events between intervention and control group will be determine.

"Timing and effect measures about the main outcome"
Risk Ratio and Risk Difference will be used as effect measures.
Difference in follow-up length will be taken into account using person-time instead of number of subjects as unit of the denominator when reporting the risks.

"Additional outcomes"
A) Evaluation of the features of adverse events. Specifically, the intention is to identify all the adverse events reported, categorize them (by 1) typology, 2) seriousness, 3) intensity and 4) time of appearance) in relation to treatment and quantify the qualitative difference of adverse events between intervention and control group.
•	Typology is defined according to the following categorisation: injection site related, muscle related, osteo-articular, neurologic, oropharyngeal, respiratory, ophthalmic, blood and circulation, infection, bowel and bladder, generalized or systemic.
•	Seriousness is defined as any untoward medical occurrence that at any dose results in death, requires hospital admission or prolongation of existing hospital stay, results in persistent or significant disability/incapacity, or is life threatening. 
•	Intensity is defined as in the grading mild moderate and severe. 
•	Time of appearance is defined as within or after the first hour.
B) Evaluate the correlation of adverse events to specific study’s population characteristic (e.g. mean age, gender prevalence)

"Timing and effect measures about additional outcomes"
A) Risk Ratios and Risk Differences will be used as effect measures.
Difference in follow-up length will be taken into account using person-time instead of number of subjects as unit of the denominator when computing the risks.
B) The beta coefficient with 95%CI will be reported for each population characteristic significatively associated to the incidence of adverse events.

All the searches will be conducted by four reviewers.
Literature search results will be uploaded to Zotero Software, a free and open-source reference management software to manage bibliographic data and related research materials to facilitate collaboration among reviewers during the study selection process. The team will develop and test screening questions based on the inclusion and exclusion criteria.
Titles and/or abstracts of studies retrieved using the search strategy and those from additional sources will be screened independently by two couples of authors to identify studies that potentially meet the inclusion criteria outlined above. The full text of these potentially eligible studies will be retrieved and assessed for eligibility by two couples of the review team members. The reasons of excluding trials will be reported. Any disagreement over the screening and eligibility of particular studies will be resolved through discussion between all authors.
To sort out the included studies and extract data, a standardised planned on Excel form will be used. 
The extraction form will be filled in by two couples of authors alternately with mutual check on each entry. Disagreements will be resolved by either consensus or consultation with a third review author.
The following data will be extracted: first author and year of publications, level of evidence, study design, sample characteristics, type of treatment of control group, number of patients in the experimental and in the control groups, formulation and maximum dose of Botulinum toxin A, location of injection, guidance techniques, number of not-adverse event related interruptions and drop-outs, number of patients with adverse effects in study groups, number of patients with adverse events of intervention and control group; total number, type, seriousness, grading of severity/intensity and time of appearance of the adverse events reported.

"Risk of bias (quality) assessment"
Two couples of review authors will independently assess the risk of bias in included studies by using the Revised Cochrane risk-of-bias tool for randomized trials (RoB 2). RoB graph will be created. The McMaster Quality Assessment Scale of Harms will be utilized to assess for adverse events and complications reporting.
Any disagreement over the assessment of risk of bias studies will be resolved through discussion between all authors.

"Strategy for data synthesis"
We will perform qualitative synthesis in order synthetize the results about the most common adverse events reported, their severity and time of appearance, relation or not-relation to botulinum toxin intervention will be evaluated. The results will be discussed according to Internal validity, clinical relevance and applicability of included studies.  We will also report both the total number and type of the adverse events, if they are local or systemic, serious or not,  their severity (mild, moderate or severe grading) and their time of appearance (within or after the first hour), even the number of participants experiencing at least one side effect will be sought (when available). Incidence of adverse events will be calculated by the Experimental Incidence Rate and the Control Incidence Rate (CER), then their ratio, their difference, the Number Need to Harm (NNH) will be reported.
Meta-analysis of data will be conducted. Statistical heterogeneity of studies will be evaluated using the I²-test. An I² value greater than 60% will be considered as substantial heterogeneity. In such cases random effects model will be used as a conservative approach to account for different sources of variation among studies, with risk ratios (RR) and risk difference (RD) as effect size for the dichotomous outcomes. The significance level will be defined as P<0.05. All the P values will be two-sided, while the weight of studies will be calculated according to the reciprocal of their variance.
Publication bias will be determine using a funnel plot, RoB graph will be used for visualize the Risk of bias.
Analysis will be completed testing the heterogeneity of adverse events' incidence. 
The meta-regression technique will be used to estimate the impact of age, gender, cause of dystonia or spasticity on adverse events' incidence using the inverse of the variance of the study-level parameter estimate as weight and adjusting for the different follow-up length.
Sensitivity analyses will be carried on conditioning on adverse events’ typology, seriousness, intensity and time of appearance and using a random effect model will be used as a conservative approach.

registration_responses.q1: William Campanella, Giulia Maggi, Sabrina Mesmaeker, ELENA SARETTI, Tiziano Innocenti, Luca Carmisciano, gianmarco rosa, Lucio Marinelli, LAURA MORI, Carlo Trompetto
registration_responses.q2: Spasticity and dystonia affect motor function and ability to perform activity of daily living, with an important impact on patients and caregivers’ quality of life. Intramuscular administration of botulinum toxin type A is one of the treatment of spastic hypertonia or dystonia. The aim of this systematic review is to evaluate the risk of any kind of local or systemic adverse events due to botulinum toxin type A injection in the management of upper and lower limb muscles spasticity and dystonia as positive features of upper motor neuron syndrome.
registration_responses.q3: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: COVID-19 Research
attributes.description: An experimental investigation to harness the global Corona response momentum in the fight against climate change

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Motivating support of information and resistance against misinformation about COVID-19

other.value:
We also measure concern about COVID-19, age, gender, news consumption regarding COVID-19, procedural news knowledge, trust in various online news outlets, and social media use.

In exploratory analyses, we will test whether intervention effects vary as a function of these variables.

sample.value: We powered our study to detect small effect sizes of d=0.15. According to a power analysis for an F-test with repeated measures and a within-between interaction using G*Power, a sample size of N=111 is required (37 per group). Based on this analysis, we plan to collect 40 participants/group.

analyses.value:
Condition (counterarguing mindset vs. nudge vs. control) and news type (0: true vs. 1: false) will be treated as dummy variables in all analyses. 

All analyses will be conducted at the level of the individual rating (one data point per item per participant) using multi-level regression models.

H1: Following Pennycook (Study 1, https://osf.io/aqvzk/), to examine H1, we will regress rating on task (0: sharing vs. 1: accuracy rating), news type and 2-way interactions between these variables. Our key prediction is that there will be a negative interaction between task and news type, such that the difference between false and true news items is smaller in the sharing task than the accuracy task.

H2-3: We will test whether sharing likelihood differs in the treatment conditions compared to the control condition by testing for an interaction between condition dummies  and a news type as well as main effects of each factor. Analyses will be performed using multi-level regression models. Our main prediction is that the treatment conditions will lead show decreased sharing of false news compared to the control condition whereas true news will be shared at either at similar or higher levels in the treatment compared to control conditions.

H4: We will test whether the likelihood to comment and react differs between the counterarguing mindset and control conditions and between the counterarguing mindset and nudge condition by testing  for an interaction between condition and a news type as well as main effects of each factor. Our key prediction is that the counterarguing mindset condition will lead to the highest likelihood to react and comment, irrespective of news type.

H5: We will test whether difference in comment and reaction valence between true and false news items is larger for the counterarguing mindset and nudge conditions than for the control condition by regressing comment and reaction valence on condition dummies and news type as well as an interaction of the factors. 

H6: The effect of promoting a counterarguing mindset compared to the control condition described in H5 will be stronger for individuals with high procedural news knowledge than for individuals with low procedural news knowledge.

outliers.value: Participants have to self-report having an account on social media (Facebook or Twitter) to participate in the study.

dependent.value:
Participants complete the same task for each of 14 news items (7 true and 7 false). For each true and false news item, participants are asked to respond to the following questions:

"We will now show you a series of news items you may come across on your social media newsfeed. For each of them, please let us know how you would respond to the post if you saw it on your social media feed."

1) "Would you add any of the following 'reactions'?" (Note: Reactions are 5 different smileys offered by Facebook to respond to posts and a "I would not add any of these reactions." option - see survey materials)
2) "How likely would you be to share this post with your network on social media?" (1: Very unlikely - 5: Very likely)
3) "How likely would you be to write a comment under the post?" (1: Very unlikely - 5: Very likely)
4) "If you were to comment on this post, what would you say? (Please write at least 25 characters)"
5. "How would you rate your comment about this post?" (1: Very negative about the post- 5: Very positive about the post)

conditions.value:
Participants are pseudo-randomly assigned to one of three conditions, so that all conditions are shown with equal frequency: 

1) Nudge: We will conceptually replicate the accuracy nudge condition used by Pennycook (https://osf.io/2jtx6/; Study 2). In this condition, participants are asked to judge the accuracy of a news item that is not related to COVID-19. This task will be introduced as unrelated to the main study. ("Before we start with the main study, we would like to ask for your help with a pre-test that we are currently conducting for a new research project. Specifically, we would like to get your opinion on the following: Based on the article headline below, do you think it is accurately describing something that actually happened?" (1: Definitely inaccurate - 5: Definitely accurate)

2) Counterarguing mindset: Based on prior work (Chaxel & Han, 2018; https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/jcpy.1003), we ask participants to indicate whether they agree or disagree with 5 statements unrelated to COVID-19 and to provide reasons for their decision. 4 of the 5 statements were chosen so that most people would be likely to disagree. One item was chosen to be more ambiguous to mask the purpose of the manipulation. Identical to the nudge conditions, the mindset condition will be introduced as unrelated to the main study. ("Before we start with the main study, we would like to ask for your help with a pre-test that we are currently doing for a new research project. Specifically, you will read a list of opinions different people have. Please answer whether you agree or disagree with these opinions and provide a reason for your decision.")

3) Control: In a third condition, participants will not be asked to do anything before completing the main task.

hypothesis.value:
H1: (Conceptual replication of research described in https://osf.io/aqvzk/ (Study 1)) The difference between false and true news (discernment) is larger for the perceived accuracy task than it is for social media sharing likelihood. 

H2: (Conceptual replication of research described in https://osf.io/aqvzk/ (Study 2)) Prompting people to think about accuracy will lead to a lower sharing likelihood for false information about COVID-19 on social media compared to the control condition.

H3: Promoting a counterarguing mindset in people will decrease the likelihood that they will be willing to share false information about COVID-19 on social media compared to the control condition.

H4: Promoting a counterarguing mindset in people will increase the likelihood that people will be willing to comment on and react to news items about COVID-19 on social media compared to the control and nudge conditions condition.

H5: Promoting a counterarguing mindset or prompting people to think about accuracy (each compared to the control condition) will lead them to write more positive comments and add more positive reactions on true news items and more negative comments and negative reactions on false news items.

H6: The effect of promoting a counterarguing mindset compared to the control condition described in H5 will be stronger for individuals with high procedural news knowledge than for individuals with low procedural news knowledge.

registration_responses.name: Motivating support of information and resistance against misinformation about COVID-19
registration_responses.other:
We also measure concern about COVID-19, age, gender, news consumption regarding COVID-19, procedural news knowledge, trust in various online news outlets, and social media use.

In exploratory analyses, we will test whether intervention effects vary as a function of these variables.
registration_responses.sample: We powered our study to detect small effect sizes of d=0.15. According to a power analysis for an F-test with repeated measures and a within-between interaction using G*Power, a sample size of N=111 is required (37 per group). Based on this analysis, we plan to collect 40 participants/group.
registration_responses.analyses:
Condition (counterarguing mindset vs. nudge vs. control) and news type (0: true vs. 1: false) will be treated as dummy variables in all analyses. 

All analyses will be conducted at the level of the individual rating (one data point per item per participant) using multi-level regression models.

H1: Following Pennycook (Study 1, https://osf.io/aqvzk/), to examine H1, we will regress rating on task (0: sharing vs. 1: accuracy rating), news type and 2-way interactions between these variables. Our key prediction is that there will be a negative interaction between task and news type, such that the difference between false and true news items is smaller in the sharing task than the accuracy task.

H2-3: We will test whether sharing likelihood differs in the treatment conditions compared to the control condition by testing for an interaction between condition dummies  and a news type as well as main effects of each factor. Analyses will be performed using multi-level regression models. Our main prediction is that the treatment conditions will lead show decreased sharing of false news compared to the control condition whereas true news will be shared at either at similar or higher levels in the treatment compared to control conditions.

H4: We will test whether the likelihood to comment and react differs between the counterarguing mindset and control conditions and between the counterarguing mindset and nudge condition by testing  for an interaction between condition and a news type as well as main effects of each factor. Our key prediction is that the counterarguing mindset condition will lead to the highest likelihood to react and comment, irrespective of news type.

H5: We will test whether difference in comment and reaction valence between true and false news items is larger for the counterarguing mindset and nudge conditions than for the control condition by regressing comment and reaction valence on condition dummies and news type as well as an interaction of the factors. 

H6: The effect of promoting a counterarguing mindset compared to the control condition described in H5 will be stronger for individuals with high procedural news knowledge than for individuals with low procedural news knowledge.

3) "How likely would you be to write a comment under the post?" (1: Very unlikely - 5: Very likely)
4) "If you were to comment on this post, what would you say? (Please write at least 25 characters)"
5. "How would you rate your comment about this post?" (1: Very negative about the post- 5: Very positive about the post)

attributes.title: Muscularity and Mating behaviors (Study 2)
attributes.description: According to the results from the first study which was conducted a year ago, in the current study we are going to examine the roles of possible third variables which may affect the relationship between intrasexual rivalry, mate retention behaviors and drive for muscularity. Considering the current literature on the subject, we speculate that result from Study 1 can be replicated after controlling for honesty-humility, drive for wealth, body mass index (BMI), and perceived body size.

item1.value: Men with higher drive for muscularity use rival-derogation intrasexual rivalry tactics and cons-inflicting mate retention behaviors.

item2.value: Muscularity is a trait evolved through sexual selection and although women prefer muscular men as their mates (both for short-term and long-term relationships), it has been shown that too much desire for muscularity is associated with elevated tetosterone and aggressive and combative behaviors which can be costly in a relationship. In Study 2 we re-conducted the analysis but this time honesty-humility, drive for wealth, body mass index (BMI), and perceived body size were included in the analysis to make sure the relationships from Study 1 exist even after controlling for these variables.

attributes.title: Assessment of Goat Production and Marketing Practices, Constraints and Opportunities in Yabello District of Borana Zone, Southern Ethiopia
attributes.description:
This research was undertaken with the objectives of assessing production and marketing practices, constraints and opportunities
of goat production in Yabello District. The results were based on surveying of 100 households and the markets monitoring in the
District. Then, the average goat holding in the woreda was 14.43 heads. Of these, female goats account a higher proportion
(48.43%) which is due to the fact that pastoralists kept their female goats longer than the male. Goats in Yabello woreda were
solely kept for the purposes of generating cashes used for purchasing grains for family consumption. Considerable, proportions
also used for meat and milk consumptions at home. In Study area various routine activities of goat production were shared
among different family members. The activities like purchasing, selling and breeding of goats were performed exclusively by the
husband. While, the husbandry roles like care of sick animal, milking, and cleaning barn, was left for women. Prominently,
children also participated in herding the flock. Selection of breeding stocks for next generation was more frequently done in
bucks (85%) than female animals in the District. Accordingly, half of the respondents were performed selection of breeding bucks
based on their body size, pedigree and growth rate. Browsing on shrubs, bushes and tree leaves were the major feed sources for
goats throughout the year. In woreda there are three local livestock market such as Haro-bake, El-waya and Yabello. Diseases of
small ruminants were the first ranked production constraints of small ruminants followed by feed shortage and water scarcity.
Keywords: Goats production, marketing system, opportunities, Yabello district

attributes.title: Beyond Happy: A Cross Cultural Study on Social Sharing of Discrete Positive Emotions
attributes.description: When people experience emotions, they often have an urge to share their emotions with others. This urge has been termed as social sharing of emotions. Previous research on social sharing of general positive events indicates that sharing positive emotions has implications to people’s daily well-being. As discrete positive emotions are valued differently in different cultures, there is a need to go beyond ‘happy’ and examine social sharing of discrete positive emotions across different cultures. In the present work we will investigate motives for and propensity to share three positive emotions (pride, gratitude and feeling moved) with participants from the Netherlands and India.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Beyond Happy: A Cross Cultural Study on Social Sharing of Discrete Positive Emotions

When people experience emotions, they often have an urge to share their emotions with others. This urge has been termed as social sharing of emotions. Previous research on social sharing of general positive events indicates that sharing positive emotions has implications to people’s daily well-being. As discrete positive emotions are valued differently in different cultures, there is a need to go beyond ‘happy’ and examine social sharing of discrete positive emotions across different cultures. In the present work we will investigate motives for and propensity to share three positive emotions (pride, gratitude and feeling moved) with participants from the Netherlands and India.

other.value:
Manipulation Check for study 1 & 2:
After  each emotion condition, participants will report the extent to which they felt all three target positive emotions. To check whether participants actually recalled an experience involving the target emotion, we will examine the effect of emotion condition (gratitude, pride, feeling moved, within subjects’) on the target emotion intensity with three separate ANOVAs and planned comparisons. 

Exploratory:
Feeling Moved:
Along with pride and gratitude, we selected the positive emotion feeling moved. Feeling moved is high in arousal, thus, it may be valued in independent cultures in terms of arousal (Tsai, 2007). On the other hand, feeling moved is socially engaging, thus, it may be valued in interdependent cultures in terms of its social engagement (Kitayama, Mesquita & Karasawa, 2006). Moreover, initial evidence suggests that people across many cultures find it less appropriate to express feeling moved (Manokara et.al., Manuscript in preparation). Given the culturally contradictory nature of feeling moved and stringent social norms for expressing this emotion, in all cross-cultural analyses, we will examine motives for and propensity to share feeling moved in an exploratory manner.

Study 1:
Preferred Sharing Partners. We will explore the most frequent sharing partners for the three positive emotions. To that end, we will describe the frequency of the five different sharing partner categories for each emotion in each culture using boxplots.

Study 2:
Frequency of sharing motives. We plan to explore the most frequent motives for sharing the three positive emotions. To that end we will describe how distribution of motives differs for each positive emotion using a boxplot and an exploratory factor analysis of the motives for social sharing scale.

sample.value:
Study 1:
N = 80, f = 0.15 at 80% power, average effect size based on Choi, Oishi, Shin & Suh, (2019) 

Study 2:
N = 80, f = 0.15 at 80% power, average effect size based on Choi, Oishi, Shin & Suh, (2019)

analyses.value:
Study 1:
Mean Propensity to Share. Across cultures we expect that mean propensity to share scores to be higher than the mid-point of the propensity to share measure, therefore greater than 3.5 on the 7-point scale.

Main Effect of Intensity of Emotion. Across cultures, we expect people to exhibit greater propensity to share intense compared to less intense positive emotions. We will therefore examine the main effect of the emotional intensity rating of the target emotion on the propensity to share that emotion with three separate linear regressions.

Interaction between positive emotions and culture. To test our prediction that people are more likely to share those positive emotions that align with their cultural values, we will examine the interaction effect of emotion condition (gratitude, pride, feeling moved, within-subjects), and country (India, Netherlands, between subjects), on the dependent variable propensity of sharing emotions with a mixed model ANOVA. We expect Indians to report greater propensity of sharing gratitude than the Dutch, and the Dutch to report greater propensity of sharing pride than Indians. We do not have a-priori predictions for feeling moved, therefore findings for this emotion condition will be exploratory (See Other). 

Study 2:
General motive behind sharing positive emotions. We predict that across cultures the general motive for sharing positive emotions is to re-experience positive emotions. To that end we will compare scores on the re-experiencing motive against the scores on the other six motives for social sharing with weighted mean comparison (t-test). For this comparison, a 1/6 weighted mean will be calculated for scores on 6 motives and will be compared against the mean on the re-experiencing motive.

Interaction between culture and positive emotions. To test our prediction that people are differentially motivated to re-experience positive emotions by sharing them, we will examine the interaction between emotion condition (gratitude, pride, feeling moved, within subjects’), and country (India, Netherlands, between subjects’), on the aggregate score of the items measuring re-experience motive for sharing positive emotions. Pair-wise comparisons will be used to probe the interaction effect. For gratitude, we expect that Indians will endorse the re-experience motive to a greater extent than the Dutch participants. For pride, we expect that Dutch participants will endorse the re-experience motive to a greater extent than Indians. We do not have a-priori predictions for feeling moved, therefore findings for this emotion condition will be exploratory(See, Other).

outliers.value:
For study 1 & 2:
Participants will be asked to report what they ate for dinner last night in the demographics section of the study as an attention check. In case participants fail the attention check, their responses will be examined to understand if the participant actually responded to all the previous questions. Only incomplete responses will then be omitted.

dependent.value:
Study 1:
Propensity of sharing emotions: To measure propensity of sharing, participants will report if they would like to (a) discuss the situation, (b) share their thoughts about the situation, (c) share their feelings with others on a 7-point scale (1= not at all, 7 = very much). The three elements are measured as the situation, thoughts about the situation and feelings are key aspects of social sharing (Rime, 2009). The responses to these three questions will be aggregated to form a measure of propensity of sharing. 

Study 2:
Motives for Social Sharing: To indicate why participants shared their feelings with others, participants will complete motives for social sharing scale (SSMS-39), which measures seven motives for sharing emotions with others (Duprez, Christophe, Rime, Congrad & Antoine, 2015). In the motives for social sharing scale, participants are asked to indicate their agreement with 39 motive statements for sharing an emotional episode on a 7-point scale (1=not at all, 7= very much). These 39 motives statements are then aggregated into seven scales measuring the seven motives for social sharing. The scores of items measuring re-experiencing motive will be used as a dependent variable.

conditions.value:
Study 1:
Participants will be assigned to all emotion conditions (pride, gratitude, feeling moved) in random order (within subjects). 
As this is a cross-cultural study, country is a between subjects condition.
Mixed design with within-between interaction.

Study 2: Same as study 1.

hypothesis.value:
Study 1:
We predict that
a) Across cultures, people’s propensity to share positive emotions, on average, to be greater than mid-point of the propensity to share measure. 
b) Across cultures people share intense positive emotions to a greater extent than less intense positive emotions. 
c) People would share culturally valued positive emotions to a greater extent than emotions that are less highly valued in their culture : 1)  Westerners (Dutch) will have a greater propensity to share pride compared to Easterners (Indians), 2) Easterners (Indians) (vs. Westerners (Dutch)) will have greater propensity to share gratitude, 3) No a-priory predictions for feeling moved (see Other).

Study 2:
a) Re-experiencing positive emotions may be an overarching motive behind sharing positive emotions : pride, gratitude and feeling moved.
b) We predict that people are differentially motivated to re-experience positive emotions by socially sharing them depending on the cultural values : (a) Westerners (Dutch) are more motivated to re-experience pride by sharing it with others as compared to Easterners (Indians) and (b) Easterners (Indians) are more motivated to re-experience gratitude by sharing it with others than are Westerners (Dutch) (c) No a-priory predictions for feeling moved (see Other).

attributes.title: Humanness From Color
attributes.description: Examining the dynamic influences of skin tone and racial category in attributions and perceptions of positive qualities.

q2.value:
-	All hypotheses are driven by evidence suggested by our previous studies, our subsequent post hoc investigations, and the existing literature. The hypotheses focus on the relation between facial skin tone group (as manipulated – lighter vs. darker) and both the targets' racial category and perceived femininity in predicting the positivity of social evaluation. 
-	Prior research has documented both the existence of pro-White racial biases in social judgments as well as efforts to avoid or conceal such biases.  Given this uncertainty, we do not offer an a priori hypothesis for an effect of target race, which will be examined on an exploratory basis.
-	Based on prior literature showing that women are generally rated as having more positive qualities than men (e.g., Eagly & Mladinic, 1994), we hypothesize that independent of race and skin tone, faces higher in feminine features will be rated as having more positive human qualities than faces lower in femininity.  
-	Based on our previous findings, we predict that faces with lighter skin tones will be seen has having more positive human qualities than faces with darker skin tones. 
-	We further predict that this main effect of skin tone will be qualified by an interaction with degree of facial femininity.  Specifically, the effect of lighter (vs. darker) skin tones in creating higher ratings of positive human qualities will be much stronger in the subset of faces that are lower in facial femininity.  That is, the effect of skin tone on attributions of positive human qualities will be significantly attenuated among faces that are higher in facial femininity.

Compensation will be determined based on the typical completion time of pilot participants, prorated from a base of $10 per hour. To be eligible for the study, participants must be
English-speaking American adults who respond correctly to a two-question “bot-check” – screening questions that are easy for English-speaking humans to answer, but which are difficult for computer programs to guess.

q11.value: -	We will recruit 600 MTurk workers to participate in our study, with an aim to have a final sample of at least 500 usable participants after exclusions.

q12.value: -	Due to the type of multilevel statistical models we employ, assessments of power using conventional methods are not straightforward. Thus, we base our sample size intentions on previous studies that we have run. In previous studies, which were within-subjects on all theory-based variables, a sample size of 250 participants has been adequate to detect meaningful effects (see https://osf.io/g8v32/). Given the adjustment in our design, in which target race (black or white) is now a between-subjects factor, we opt to double our sample size (thus maintaining 250 participants per between-subjects condition) and expect that this will be sufficient for detecting effects that are comparable to those that we have found in previous studies.

question.value:
-	Our three manipulated theoretical variables are target skin tone, target race, and perceived femininity of the target. 
-	Target race is manipulated by selecting male faces that are tagged as African American or as White in the Chicago Face Database. We used faces with neutral facial affect and a direct, camera-facing pose. This variable is manipulated between-subjects.
-	The two levels of perceived femininity will be operationalized by norming data associated with each target face in the Chicago Face Database (Ma, Correll, & Wittenbrink, 2015) norming data. High-femininity targets were created using faces that were rated in the highest quartile on perceived femininity for their respective racial group, whereas low-femininity targets were created using faces in the lowest quartile of perceived femininity. To reduce idiosyncratic facial features, we morphed pairs of faces that fell into the same race-by-femininity category to create the stimulus faces. That is, pairs of faces that were identified as high-feminine Black men in the face database were morphed together, as were faces identified as low-feminine Black men, as high-feminine White men, and as low-feminine White men. This procedure was intended to create faces that more prototypically (less idiosyncratically) embody the qualities of race and facial femininity. All morphs were created using the FantaMorph by Abrosoft photo morphing software. 
-	The two levels of the skin tone variable will be operationalized by digitally manipulating each of the morphed target images into both a lightened skin tone and a darkened skin tone version using Adobe Photoshop. Faces in the group consisting of Black targets with lightened skin tone have Adobe Photoshop (CC 2018) Luminosity values at or very near 135, faces in the group consisting of Black targets with darkened skin tone have Adobe Photoshop (CC 2018) Luminosity values at or very near 60, faces in the group consisting of White targets with lightened skin tone have Adobe Photoshop (CC 2018) Luminosity values at or very near 175, and faces in the group consisting of White targets with darkened skin tone have Adobe Photoshop (CC 2018) Luminosity values at or above 100. 
-	As previously described, there is also one methodological variable. The stimulus set variable involves manipulating which particular faces in a given stimulus set are lightened and which ones are darkened. The half that are lightened in Set A will be darkened in Set B, and vice versa.

-	Our primary outcome variables are:
We will collect ratings of each face in terms of 4 positive human qualities related to communality: trustworthy, friendly, honest, and warm (Abele et al., 2016). Participants will be asked how well the traits fit each face on a 0 (not at all) to 10 (very much) sliding scale. 
-	The demographic and individual difference variables of interest are participant age, education, gender identity, race/ethnicity, sexual orientation, and political ideology. We will also collect participants' immediate reactions to the study, including a question regarding whether they took the study seriously.

-	Several composite indices will be computed for analysis:
1. For each face, we will compute the mean attribution of positive human traits (trustworthy, friendly, honest, and warm) in each of the conditions. Thus, each score will be the mean of 4 items.  
2. We will compute a summary index of each participant’s overall tendency to show colorism bias, by subtracting (for the composite variable outlined above) their mean rating of the darker group of faces from their mean rating of the lighter group of faces. For exploratory purposes, we will also compute a summary index of each participant’s overall tendency to show a femininity bias by subtracting (for the composite variable outlined above) their mean rating of the low femininity faces from their mean rating of the high femininity faces

-	All analyses will be conducted using partially cross-classified multilevel modeling. In these models, we will include two random intercepts: a random intercept of participant (which adjusts for the fact that observations are nested within person), and a random intercept of stimulus image (which adjusts for the fact that observations are nested within stimuli). These models will be conducted by regressing our dependent variables onto contrasts codes (two within-subjects and one between-subjects). One contrast will test whether lighter-skinned targets are judged differently than darker-skinned targets (light = 0.5, dark = -0.5); another contrast will examine whether white targets are judged differently than black targets (white = 0.5, black = -0.5); the final will examine whether targets perceived as high in femininity are judged differently than targets perceived as low in femininity (high = 0.5, low = -0.5). In addition, we will examine each two-way interaction (Target Race × Target Skin Tone, Target Race × Target Femininity, and Target Skin tone × Target Femininity) and the three-way interaction (Target Race × Target Skin Tone × Target Femininity).

q19.value: -	We will use the conventionally accepted statistical inference criteria of Null Hypothesis Significance Tests, with a two-tailed alpha specified at .05.

q20.value:
-	One of the final questions of our survey asks participants to report whether or not they took the study seriously (with no consequences for their compensation). Another question asks respondents to indicate whether they were distracted while completing the survey. We recognize that distractions and emotional volatility are particularly high currently because of the COVID-19 pandemic. We will exclude any participants who explicitly respond that they did not take the study seriously or who “Strongly Agree” that they were distracted while completing the survey. Our primary analyses will focus on the data set that remains with these exclusions in place, but we will also conduct the analyses including all respondents who complete the study and report any differences in findings or conclusions that result.
-	Also, we will rely on guidelines for identifying and excluding outliers as suggested by Leys et al., 2019. Thus, we will correct or delete obvious erroneous values, and use the Median Absolute Deviation method to identify univariate outliers. We will exclude any participants who qualify as multivariate outliers according to the Minimum Covariance Determinant method. Subsequently, we will run all analyses both including all data points and with univariate outliers excluded. Any changes that result from outlier inclusion/exclusion for our research findings will be explicitly noted in research reports.  
-	In addition, because data quality deteriorates when participants spend too much time off-task in the middle of an experiment (e.g., multitasking; see Clifford & Jerit, 2014), we will use excessively long survey completion times as a basis for participant exclusion.  In a pilot test of our procedures, we determined that participants took an average of approximately 5 minutes to complete the survey and few needed more than 6 minutes.  As a conservative indicator of excessive off-task activity, we will exclude any participants whose survey completion times exceed 15 minutes (i.e., 3x the average time taken in the pilot test). In addition, as a conservative indicator of excessively fast survey completion times, we will exclude any participants whose survey completion times are less than 1 minute and 40 seconds (100 seconds). We chose this cutoff based on the completion time distribution for a similar previous study of comparable length. Again, we will run the analyses both with and without these exclusions to determine if there are differences in results based on exclusions.

q22.value: -	We will examine whether patterns of skin tone and facial femininity bias are moderated by political ideology, age, or gender.

registration_responses.q2:
-	All hypotheses are driven by evidence suggested by our previous studies, our subsequent post hoc investigations, and the existing literature. The hypotheses focus on the relation between facial skin tone group (as manipulated – lighter vs. darker) and both the targets' racial category and perceived femininity in predicting the positivity of social evaluation. 
-	Prior research has documented both the existence of pro-White racial biases in social judgments as well as efforts to avoid or conceal such biases.  Given this uncertainty, we do not offer an a priori hypothesis for an effect of target race, which will be examined on an exploratory basis.
-	Based on prior literature showing that women are generally rated as having more positive qualities than men (e.g., Eagly & Mladinic, 1994), we hypothesize that independent of race and skin tone, faces higher in feminine features will be rated as having more positive human qualities than faces lower in femininity.  
-	Based on our previous findings, we predict that faces with lighter skin tones will be seen has having more positive human qualities than faces with darker skin tones. 
-	We further predict that this main effect of skin tone will be qualified by an interaction with degree of facial femininity.  Specifically, the effect of lighter (vs. darker) skin tones in creating higher ratings of positive human qualities will be much stronger in the subset of faces that are lower in facial femininity.  That is, the effect of skin tone on attributions of positive human qualities will be significantly attenuated among faces that are higher in facial femininity.
